FD5pZ6a3JFM-MCJTV5RxVw.text: I'm an American so I know what I'm talkin' bout.  Okay, the burgers were OKAY, I have to give it to them for making them from scratch rather then using pre-prepared patties.  The thing is, they serve them in baskets.  What is this?  Dennys?  The burgers themselves are quite messy and its kind of like drinking water out of a siv.  Also, way to small.The fries.  Oh hell no.  They were shoestring fries.  No real American diner would ever sell shoestring fries honey.  Sort it out.The milkshakes were pretty good.  I recommend the chocolate with peanut butter.  They could be thicker though.  Also, WAY OVERPRICED.I can see where they're going with the decor, but it's still pretty English to me.  Good music though.I have yet to try more food.  Gonna go back for breakfast and see how that works out.  Wish me luck.  I'm hungry and missing American diner food!

9gFzUZvRCKbHQySY0f4pZw.text: Okay, I'll have to admit, this is a somewhat skewed review coming from a Canadian and an American who have been away for 7 years, but North American ex-pats can likely relate, and may want to read this as 4 of 5 stars, especially if you're missing home. The theme is essentially 50's diner Americana; from the decor, to the music, to the staff 'uniforms'. The menu is quintessential American grub from the last half of the 1900's... well, except for the free wi-fi. Flipping through the menu brought us back, and in all honesty, the menu is more American than most of these types of restaurants in the US (and Canada)! One potential weakness of this franchise in the UK is that American grub like this from the last half of the 1900's isn't the benchmark of gourmet and quality ingredients, has never pretended to be, and wouldn't be what it is if it was the 'benchmark'. Think of this food as the USA equivalent to the S&M Cafe or a greasy spoon diners outside a zone 3 tube station full of tradesmen having a English breakfast; good, tasty, stick to the ribs food. Next time you feel like fast-food, kick it up a notch and try this place for a sit down meal in a fun, funky atmosphere.

riTfX9I34LlAm8HMKHlmDQ.text: I want to give this place more star, but it fell short for my unfortunately. That said, I was so hungover yesterday that I didn't care too much. I rather strangely ordered a Caesar Salad and it wasn't great - the chicken was dry. But the dressing was yum and the croutons were very good. I wasn't exactly eating much due to aforementioned hangover so maybe I'd have been happier if I was feeling OK. I did order a side of hashbrowns though and they were yummy indeed. Everyone else's lunch looked much nicer than mine - maybe I just chose the wrong thing. Still, I'm not sure my whole meal should have set me back over £12. But that doesn't really explain why we had to wait so long. First before we sat down - we could see five or so empty tables, but we stood about for around ten minutes. Then we didn't get served for ages. Our food then took a good twenty minutes to arrive. Our waitress was nice, but we had to ask her if we could order and she looked a bit dazed. Maybe she was as hungover as us. I want to like it here, but I wasn't overly blown away with the Soho branch either - it's just a stop gap. Nothing special. The food is sometimes good, but service is very hit and miss. It's a nice place, but after trying Diner a couple of times, I might have to look elsewhere for my American food fix.

sEeVjEHHbZ-nOLV_6cEWJQ.text: One of the most authentic American Diner's I have come across in London, and knocks the socks off of Ed's. Incredibly authentic and eclectic menu, so vast that I'm sure you could eat here every week for an entire year and never eat the same thing twice. Popped here for a hot choc and short stack of pancakes with my friend yesterday afternoon and then stayed and waited for my boyfriend to join me for dinner before heading to the Garage for a gig. It cost us around £30 for 2 root beer floats, a burger each and some cheese fries, which is a little on the expensive side, but definitely worth it as the quality of the food is great and the service was fantastic. Will definitely be returning and looking up the one off of Carnaby St which is closer to the Saaf where we live. They could definitely do with opening one south of the river too. They'd make a killing in Clapham/Battersea!

bOQPtEo_N9xXRZ7I_o6WYw.text: Only problem we had with the staff was trying to get their attention once. Food was good, not great. It is quite pricey for what you get. I had a chicken burrito. Milkshakes are great and free, fast wifi is a bonus.

Lk1-iDt-YrxhzXCSAgNwXw.text: I'm not saying this is authentic Stateside diner food - it's way too expensive and the service a little ramshackle to measure up to the high-velocity calorific exuberance that is American eating - but it's a damn good try. The burgers are substantial, the fries crispy, and the milkshakes reassuringly concrete in texture (although, aren't they a little smaller than they were a few months back?). The red leathery booths and friendly waitresses warm the cockles, and you don't even have to ask for napkins. A welcome addition to London, although if you're forced to choose, go to the Shoreditch one instead.

nJmwfBdoQmFTp1fSQAtOaA.text: We went into the Diner for a snack and some milkshakes. The milshakes were nice, but small and overpriced. The shakes come with the base milkshake and the flavour that you mix yourself from a separate cup. We also had fries which were ok, but again a little over priced. The place was very busy and service wasnt excelent as a result. Having said this I have visited the camden branch of The Diner and had a good experience with the burgers there.

TG2JqctqqCKzggSP7Pmq1Q.text: The food was ok, but very expensive for what is really burger and fries. A Philly cheese steak, fries, black beans and a beer, £17.64 with service. The service was good and had a decent range of American beer.

0288yQ477LTP6Qky4l9DDg.text: We just had lunch at this "So called" American diner. There is very little about American style burgers and a lot about London prices. Food quality was adequate, nothing special; I have had tastier burgers from a chain. Nothing about American size portions here either, the burgers we had were pretty small. The service was simply bad as we struggled to get the waitress attention. Maybe it was one of those days... However, nothing out of the ordinary on those burgers. Advice: If you walked passed this place many times and wondered how food would be like... keep walking. L

UpuSgaAb0IjlMCNhi3lOTQ.text: Was met by a pretty wairess who was very attentive throughout. Unusual beer available which was very good. The burgers were excellent but the coleslaw left a bit to be desired.

jP6WaQJWWepPCGDE2DEdiQ.text: About three or four few years ago, The Diner was always my go-to burger/milkshake/comfort food joint. However, over the past few years the standard has plummeted. I've thought this for a while and every now and then I revisit one of the restaurants in the hope of reviving my The Diner experience. Every time I'm left disappointed however. I went to the Angel restaurant over the weekend and had the Eggs Benedict; the muffins were stale, the hollandaise sauce was cold and the whole thing was just a bit meh. The milkshakes are consistently good so perhaps I'll pop in for a Hard Shake from time to time. However, until it steps up its game and returns to its former glory, me and The Diner are through!

VcEwtWJ-pU5h7_Zp38HXaw.text: Strangely, despite it's bad rep, I always have a great time when I go to this branch of the Diner. Perhaps it's the company (I only ever go here to meet one of my close friends - and our monthly meal is now the only time I see her) but I've also enjoyed the food too. Usually, we meet for brunch and I get pancakes with a side of chorizo. Sweet blueberry pancakes with spicy chorizo is just a flavour win in my book. This time, however, it was to try to Diablo burger which is rumoured to be one of the best in London. As a self proclaimed burger aficionado, I had to try it to find out.First off, the damn thing is massive so a size win! Too often, the burger is tasty but too small to really satisfy (I'm looking at you, Burger & Shake). This thing is a hefty two-hander with a patty the size of some longhorn cattle. The patty was a tad over cooked (more medium than requested medium rare) but still juicy enough to be enjoyable. The meat selection could have done with a bit more beefy sirloin taste to give it more body. So, decent patty but not worthy of a top spot by any measure.The bun was a bit boring to be honest and fell apart halfway through. I think it was a generic white bread bun so overall - epic fail.Toppings consisted of melted cheese and lots of chilli. Now this was my type of burger! Sadly, while tasty, it lacked the level of heat I had been led to expect and had hoped for. Maybe for the average Englishman it was on fire, but for one brought up on curry instead of applesauce, it just wasn't good enough.Overall, a perfectly enjoyable burger although a bit pricey at around 13 squids. I won't be back for the burger (but will be for pancakes and the company) as there are many better tasting and better value options around!

fjW9ZISVZQ7OV8Wt3OY9iQ.text: Holy cow Batman!I went here for their Thanksgiving/Christmas meal, and was super impressed! The menu was creative in their take on American foods (macaroni and cheese pops anyone?) and everything was absolutely delicious. The buttered rum was pretty weak both in terms of flavour and rum, but at least they tried. Now after all the effort, none of the music was American. Having asked about the tunes, the poor waitress informed us she had no say in the music and had a few people pointing out the same misstep.  The complaint I do have is that the dessert was incredibly poor, and two of my group had paper in our desserts. Obviously our dessert were shipped to the restaurant, and the paper that wrapped it was included. I am guessing because we lacked fiber in our diets.

K_w183WN9JXdeK2YQd1ifQ.text: So shockingly bad.But I'm a sucker for a booth and a milkshake.

f-3eGAwipPKTUCuHV5SetA.text: This place has some of the best shakes that I have tasted; the hard shakes are particularly delicious, but be warned with the high liquor content they are not for kids or the faint hearted. The booths were a little uncomfortable but there was a good ambience to the place.

wYRGE-KZojPUvlxwwIl5aQ.text: I was so disappointed by this place. I was really excited about going here - I love American style breakfasts. My boyfriend and I were extremely hungover and we thought it would be the perfect opportunity to get some fatty American style food! We managed to get a little team of sore heads together, about 6 of us, and off we went really hungry and excited.....As we walked in the decor and big black and white menu on the wall looked really authentic... that's all that was good really. Our waitress came over and we were all in quite a silly, hungover, jokey mood - she did not want to join in....or smile for that matter. All of our food arrived at different times - two people had to wait ages for theirs. We were all almost finished by the time it arrived. The food was ok - but not worth the price at all - could of gone to a greasy spoon...... you get the tiniest pot of maple syrup too if you order pancakes :( This place could be really good if they just stepped it up a little. Train your staff, more love/thought into the food and try to be a little more unique and special?

_PTCdj7OYYXysgV2WR9xzA.text: A lovely place to sit but perhaps the most forgettable piece of meat I have ever encountered.

zdwUfpdDxVpFeDcxMFCcnw.text: A friend of mine warned me about this place, but I ended up going anyways because another friend invited me. The food is really gross, and it's not exactly that cheap considering what it is that you're paying for. I had the worse Monte Cristo sandwich of my life.Our waitress was friendly, but she seemed like she may have been drunk as I witnessed her dropping utensils multiple times and she said she would ask her "mammager" if he could change our big bills for us. One unique thing is that they offer this Mexican chili beer. But when it comes to quality of food, I would just say stay away from this place.

MBx9-tmshMVhkNX5tO9rmw.text: Like so many others, this was not my first choice brunch venue.  With snow pouring down from the sky, my fellow compatriots and I decided the Breakfast Club queue was too long and we needed shelter.After a long wait for our food and a rude waitress who was not keen for a laugh, I was not pleased. As my pancakes were dry and the amount of syrup given couldn't even cover a whole pancake, I decided to salvage what was left of the morning by drinking heavily, to which I was pleased to find they had Brooklyn Lager in bottles.My fellow travellers Cole O and Lucien HD, whose meals looked much better than mine, also joined my activity. Yet we would continually run out of beer despite ordering numerous times from multiple waitresses.I came back to this place a second time for the brunch and Brooklyn Lager only to find that they had run out, which meant that my Brooklyn Breakfast plan was routed. Disappointed once again.Best to bite the bullet and wait in the queue for the Breakfast Club.

f0TZpYi4hSAFPAW1y3v64g.text: The Diner @ Islington - Pics at The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) In my quest to find the best burger in London, Dr G and I went to The Diner on Essex Road, Islington. It was well after 10pm and only a day before New Year 's Eve when we visited, but this newly opened American style diner was reasonably busy. The decor recreates an American 1950s diner, with booths of red leatherette chairs and long formica tables. The menu looked impressive with a long list of all day breakfast items, costing between £6 and £8.50, like blueberry or banana pancakes, huevos rancheros, and eggs Benedict among others.Drink choices were also extensive  The Diner sells beer by the bottle or on draught with a pint of lager costing as little as £3.20. Milkshakes are priced at £4.20 while hardshakes (alcoholic milkshakes) cost £7. I ordered a Creamy Nut Hardshake (hazelnut and pistachio ice-creams with Baileys) @ £7. This took a little while to arrive but was well worth the wait as it was indeed very creamy, nutty and surprisingly alcoholic. Soon enough the rest of our order arrived. I went for the Californian Burger (Monterey Jack cheese and Guacamole) @ £6.20. All burgers are served with tomato, lettuce, red onions, gherkins and relish. It looked well presented and the 7 oz patty was quite chunky. As I bit into the burger my heart sank  the bread was not only cold but it was hard and stale; the meat was completely tasteless and overcooked (I had ordered it medium) and the guacamole tasted straight out of a jar.Dr G had ordered the Philly Cheese Steak Sandwich (Swiss cheese and grilled onions) @ £7. Again this was disappointing  stale and chewy bread, gristly meat making the sandwich virtually inedible. To accompany our sandwiches, we also made the mistake of ordering a portion of Diner's Chilli Cheese Fries (topped with cheese and hot chilli beef) @ £3.50. The fries were not only cold but were also hard, undercooked and greasy. I really cannot find anything positive to say about these fries and the greasy, synthetic orange cheese smothered over the most undistinguished chilli beef. Verdict  one of the worst burgers I have ever eaten, stale bread, and under-cooked, greasy fries. Good hardshakes were the only redeeming feature. There are many better options for a burger in Islington and London. Stay away!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

XqOpe3mXR-snYsyAeccOWg.text: They have free wi-fi. Yeah, that's about it. You'll find me here, frequently, because it's quiet, they have cheese fries and free wifi. You can drink an overprice milkshake, listen to cool music and surf. The food is overpriced and mediocre. But did I mention the wifi?

IMbmyxqv4TTjin2G4eTvbA.text: Okay, I'll have to admit, this is a somewhat skewed review coming from a Canadian and an American who have been away for 7 years, but North American ex-pats can likely relate, and may want to read this as 4 of 5 stars, especially if you're missing home.The theme is essentially 50's diner Americana; from the decor, to the music, to the staff 'uniforms'. The menu is quintessential American grub from the last half of the 1900's... well, except for the free wi-fi.Flipping through the menu brought us back, and in all honesty, the menu is more American than most of these types of restaurants in the US (and Canada)!One potential weakness of this franchise in the UK is that American grub like this from the last half of the 1900's isn't the benchmark of gourmet and quality ingredients, has never pretended to be, and wouldn't be what it is if it was the 'benchmark'. Think of this food as the USA equivalent to the S&M Cafe or a greasy spoon diners outside a zone 3 tube station full of tradesmen having a English breakfast; good, tasty, stick to the ribs food.Next time you feel like fast-food, kick it up a notch and try this place for a sit down meal in a fun, funky atmosphere.

DWYsk51bHBKP-hUzJsob1A.text: This is by no means an 100% authentic American diner experience, but it is on the other hand a fun experience.Friendly staff will keep you occupied at the bar if its busy with their wide range of 'Hard' alcoholic milkshakes, or softer ones if you'd prefer, and beers and wines and soft drinks. (Although I hear the wine selection leaves a lot to be desired).The all day breakfasts are lip-smackingly good especially if you have them in the morning. Burgers are great and they even ask you how cooked you want them. There are plenty of optional burger toppings too.Service was a bit slow but made up for by friendliness. The bill was a bit heavy and I'm disappointed by places which charge for little pots of sour cream and other obvious dressings like that but hey ho.Would recommend it for large groups or a date.

V1quGMIS3Lj7bbBVvFLh2g.text: We ended up here because we were in a rush and the lines at the Breakfast Club, Elk in the Woods and S&M were too long.  Well, we could have waited in the Breakfast Club queue 15 deep and still would have got out faster than at the Diner.  We were seated immediately, but the whole event took forever.  The food took a long time and getting the bill took a long time and never did the waitress bother to give us a friendly notice or acknowledgement during that time or refill my cup of coffee without waving her down.  I had heard they had good blueberry pancakes and regretted not ordering them because my huevos rancheros were basically disgusting.  The beans were SOOOO bad--maybe they spiced them with oregano and basil?  Some flavor was so off--the pico sucked and the guac was nasty!.Just in general, not a fan.

gSHr7fZoyeqwuW3mzEiIcw.text: It should be pretty easy to not totally mess up a Sunday morning brunch service, right?  It probably won't be busy, the customers aren't expecting the finest dining experience of their lives, and brunch food (especially diner brunch food) isn't all that complex.  But then this theory came up against Sunday brunch at The Diner ...The Diner is a good name for what it is: diner food (bacon, eggs, burgers, pancakes) in a trying-to-be-a diner setting (many nice large booths, big counter).  But the food was not great and our main server, while well-meaning and likeable, was somewhat inexperienced and hapless.  A mug of coffee came with the remnants of lipstick on the rim (how can this escape notice?), and the cutlery seemed less than clean.  (Though maybe we started inspecting it harder after discovering the lipstick on the mug.)

mgzHMUCTN4hndkLdlhGydA.text: It wouldn't be an overstatement to refer to The Diner as the Ryanair of precocious fast food joints. Cutting corners and charging for every little extra à la that great British bastion of cut price travel.Don't get me wrong. I like the concept. Diner is as bright and quirky as its invariably hot staff. Its menu epic and at times original but alas the quality of its food simply isn't up to scratch. I ordered the Cajun Spiced Chicken Burger for a hearty £6.50 plus £0.70 - SEVENTY PENCE! - for a slice of cheese and was greeted by an unexceptional and battered looking bit of what resembled reconstituted chicken with a decidedly un-cajun flavoured crust. Must try harder.

zGtPFaEm4uz7FmjzVVjdaQ.text: An all day breakfast especially on a sat/ sun morning? Pancakes or burgers after a heavy night? I think this place rocks, nothing special - might even be a bit over-priced BUT (and it's a big but), I love their breakfast, burgers,  and who can say no to a lovely, yummy (quite big) milkshake?Try it! (No refunds though if it wasn't good :)

GUhohdIuCfTiOKD7HkYkfA.text: The Diner @ Islington - Pics at The London FoodieIn my quest to find the "best" burger in London, Dr G and I went to The Diner on Essex Road, Islington. It was well after 10pm and only a day before New Year 's Eve when we visited, but this newly opened American style diner was reasonably busy.The decor recreates an American 1950s diner, with booths of red leatherette chairs and long formica tables.The menu looked impressive with a long list of all day breakfast items, costing between £6 and £8.50, like blueberry or banana pancakes, huevos rancheros, and eggs Benedict among others.Drink choices were also extensive - The Diner sells beer by the bottle or on draught with a pint of lager costing as little as £3.20. Milkshakes are priced at £4.20 while "hardshakes" (alcoholic milkshakes) cost £7.I ordered a "Creamy Nut Hardshake" (hazelnut and pistachio ice-creams with Baileys) @ £7. This took a little while to arrive but was well worth the wait as it was indeed very creamy, nutty and surprisingly alcoholic.Soon enough the rest of our order arrived. I went for the "Californian Burger" (Monterey Jack cheese and Guacamole) @ £6.20. All burgers are served with tomato, lettuce, red onions, gherkins and relish. It looked well presented and the 7 oz patty was quite chunky. As I bit into the burger my heart sank - the bread was not only cold but it was hard and stale; the meat was completely tasteless and overcooked (I had ordered it medium) and the guacamole tasted straight out of a jar.Dr G had ordered the "Philly Cheese Steak Sandwich" (Swiss cheese and grilled onions) @ £7. Again this was disappointing - stale and chewy bread, gristly meat making the sandwich virtually inedible.To accompany our sandwiches, we also made the mistake of ordering a portion of Diner's "Chilli Cheese Fries" (topped with cheese and hot chilli beef) @ £3.50. The fries were not only cold but were also hard, undercooked and greasy. I really cannot find anything positive to say about these fries and the greasy, synthetic orange cheese smothered over the most undistinguished chilli beef.Verdict - one of the worst burgers I have ever eaten, stale bread, and under-cooked, greasy fries. Good "hardshakes" were the only redeeming feature. There are many better options for a burger in Islington and London. Stay away!

XeEHr0YYpxvbzBiosSo4nQ.text: Great burgers and milkshakes, and good atmosphere (with the booth seating), but can be hit and miss with some of the dishes.  Free filter coffee refills is a definite plus.Other pluses: Kid friendly - there's a little play area and some (old but usable) toys and books.  Baby seats and baby changing facilities available.we've been there twice now and on both occasions, most of the meals have been very good, but one or more of the meals unacceptable or disappointing. To their credit, both times we complained, the items were removed from the bill, so don't be afraid to speak up.So, do go for : Burgers, pancakes, milkshakes, eggs benedict, western eggs (excellent on both visits!), mexican breakfast, kids omelette,  filter coffeeDon't go for : kids macaroni cheese (way way too much garlic), hungry man's breakfast  (squeezed on to too small a plate and not great value), hot dog (boring and overpriced).

oJzgPobreDviM-E7exqsMg.text: I really wanted to like this place but the service and food quality do not hit the standard set by the decor and the prices. My particular experience involved getting served oven chips instead of american style fries because they had run out. This would not have been a problem normally if they had at the very least: 1) warned me of the switch 2) lowered the price of the fries Sadly neither happened. I had to query it with no offer to compensate me.

WOdE3DRelIJCKRYUXEz0WA.text: We had a great experience at this diner. Our waitress was friendly and attentive to us. My burger was slathered generously with blue cheese and cooked to Medium perfection. My partner's burger was also perfectly done. We shared French fries, which were crispy and fresh from the fryer. They called American Cheese: US sliced cheese. Cute.

c1ty-RMVsUCXyaEK003W5Q.text: First time at 'the diner' with friends who have been to other locations. We were a large party but ordered pretty simple (and repetitive) dishes.The service was absolutely awful... the place was pretty empty but you cannot get a waitress to come and check on you to save your life... My husband and I came in a few minutes late and it took over 20 min to be noticed and given menus... one of our friends never got his food and had to tell the staff about it, 30 min later he got his food..We had to ask for the check 3 times...Bad bad bad..The only saving grace was their food.. red velvet pancakes were amazing!Will never be back

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Red velvet pancakes
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Gluten free bun with a burger and 2 types of fries

OXQBPmFKkGeLeW2H-1l1iQ.text: I enjoyed all the food I ordered! My friend and I asked for the veggie menu and ordered the seitan and waffles, vegan benedict, vegan mac and cheese, and coconut milkshake. We ate all of it and were really happy about how many vegan and vegetarian options were offered. We will definitely try to return to try more from the veggie menu!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Vegan Benedict, seitan and waffles, and vegan mac and cheese. So good!

kgMlbGc55DILKPvXs_SC7Q.text: As a chain, I'm a big fan of The Diner. But I think that just enhances my disappointment when I visit this branch, as I know how much better it could be. I've visited this branch on 3 occasions now, and my experience has always been the same. We're now at the point at which it isn't worth giving them another go.This time I visited on a Saturday afternoon, at which time there were only 4 other parties seated. Yet service and length of time to receive anything was abysmal. 10 minutes to have our drinks order taken, another 20 to receive those drinks. And another 20 for our food.We ordered 2 starters (bacon jalapeño tater tots and freakshow chicken), 2 burgers (cheeseburger and the Diablo) and sweet potato fries with garlic butter. Annoyingly our starters arrived at the same time as our burgers, despite me being clear at the time of ordering that they were wanted as starters.As it has been every time I've been to this branch, my burger was overcooked. The server did actually ask how I would like it cooked, and as medium rare is as rare as they'll do, that was my choice. She may as well have not bothered as my burger could only be described as well done. Very disappointing. The Diablo is actually one of my favourite burgers in London when cooked properly, as it has been at every other branch of The Diner that I've visited. So for me to only want to eat half of it speaks volumes.My companion had similar thoughts on his cheeseburger - which actually had very little cheese.The rest of the food was lovely. I highly recommend the tater tots.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

UfJFGzVwfnX_ZToe8iQNGA.text: Had a very interesting experience here. Interesting because it started off really bad and then turned out relatively OK at the end.To start off, I was really leery on going here, as, a straight up NYer, I know diners, and I know diners well, and I'm really sceptical London can replicate diner awesomeness. (In some respects, it already fails as it closes at midnight. No self-respecting diner in NY or NJ does that).We arrived here last Saturday night, around 11pm, feeling hangry after drinking at an all-day party. I got the vegan breakfast (Mushrooms, chickpea patties, spinach, tomatoes, avocado and sesame sauce), my friend ordered the veggie breakfast burrito ( Scrambled eggs, black beans, spinach, mushrooms, guacamole and cheese with fruit) and my husband a burger.My husband wanted coffee and the waitress/manager told him the restaurant didn't serve it that late. It had stopped making it a few hours before. She said she had never gotten a request for coffee that late, which a) I found that hard to believe and b) seemed a dismissal of a customer's tastes. My husband was flabbergasted.Took a while for our food, like others have said. Mine was actually pretty tasty....but missing avo. My friend was served her burrito only to discover she was given the meat burrito. Now this is where it all starts to go downhill.My friend sent hers back and said she had requested the veg version; the manager said she had not and said to get the veg version she would have to pay for it. My friend agreed but we all agreed this is EXACTLY how shitty customer service in the UK plays out. I also told her my avo was missing and was asked, "Do you still want it?" Uh, I paid for this, so yes.I got my avo on a side plate, with apologies... and then the manager retracted her comments and ended up substituting the veg burrito at no extra charge. So, all in all, um ok???

jPQh1UgjoCodXJrOb04gQA.text: I've been to The Diner before, but not for a while as it's previously been fine, but not great. Sadly it fell into this category once again this time around. Things are starting to wear in the restaurant - the table we sat on is a bit wonky and the seat had a tear. The menu however has improved - I had the freakshow chicken, while Nickie had the corndogs and we shared a portion of the bacon covered tater tots and onion rings.They brought regular tater tots initially, but we sent them back and afterwards got the bacon covered type. The portions are good - the corn dog basket comes with two corn dogs, the onion rings could have still been served to someone else after we ate all the ones we wanted. I particularly liked the freakshow chicken - buttermilk fried chicken strips served with Frank's wing sauce. They don't say it's Franks, but I know that taste (it's my preferred hot sauce) and so I was very happy with that. In fact, I'd say that chicken was the best thing I've had here. I appreciate the tots and the corndogs - those aren't easy to find in the UK, but the corndogs aren't battered and fried to order, they've certainly been fried beforehand and then re-heated. They took a while to take our plates away - I suspect because the portions were so big that our plates didn't look entirely clear. After ten minutes of waiting I stacked the baskets and they got the hint at that point. Like I said, overall it was fine.

PAYPZHJzLJghTLKasqixHQ.text: Eh. It's fine. This was the first branch of The Diner I went to, and I've been back a few times and never been that impressed. I thought I didn't even much like it there until I tried another branch and realised that I do like it, so I came back to this one, thinking it was the passage of time that had improved the chain.Unfortunately this branch is still mediocre. I got the same food I had at the Seven Dials branch a couple of months ago, and here it wasn't as good, nor was the service as good. I had corn dogs and bacon & jalapeño tater tots. We were the only people there, pretty much, and our food was still slow to come - and then it was wrong. They brought me a basket of plain tots, and when I said that wasn't what I ordered, they were whisked away without much of an apology, and the replacement was slow to come. When they finally came, when I was more than halfway done (even though I was eating slowly) they were fine, but the cheese sauce dip came cold - like fridge cold, instead of melted like the other branch. Plus the jalapenos were red - now, I know jalapenos do come in a red variety, but it's not something I've come across in London before. I assume these were not jalapenos (as they were spicer) and I would have preferred a heads up.The corn dogs were nice.Definitely avoiding this branch in the future. There was no atmosphere - the music stopped abruptly for a good 5 minutes, and when it came back on, it was so loud we couldn't speak any more (we were still pretty much the only table there). The booth seating was cracked and uncomfortable. You could be so much better, Diner.

YwQaC5eOboPDLvsVPQQoSg.text: We were pretty desperate and didn't want to wait in line at The Breakfast club so decided to give this place a shot. Nice clean decor and friendly hostess. We had been warned off the breakfast tortilla by my friend who lives nearby which he said is essentially a bag of Doritos with some breakfast stuff thrown on top. I had the Hungry Man's breakfast and it was ok. My fiancee has the egg muffin and it was ok too. That's really all I have to say about this place - it's ok. The Elk in the Woods and The Breakfast Club are both better nearby alternatives and even a local greasy spoon cafe would be at least as good and cheaper

jQFeUhmfr0uy2Is3zlKtjg.text: Hi there! Your local American here! I went in to The Diner expecting it to be pretty terrible, but I've been so curious about how it was that I decided to spend a dinner on it. The overall opinion: not great, but some surprisingly decent things:The good: My cheeseburger was really pretty great. Topped just how I asked for it to be, and cooked to perfection. Also, I saw they have chili cheese fries, but they also have tater tots under the breakfast menu. So, I asked if they'd make me chili cheese tater tots, and while they weren't totally authentic, they were totally tasty. I'd have that again. The bad: The service. They were totally nice, but completely understaffed... one girl tending bar, and one guy running around doing seemingly all of the waiting. I'm actually writing this review while I wait on my bill, and have waited for about 15 minutes. (Editorial note: the guy came around with the bill about a minute after I wrote that.) No fault of the people working here... they're working their tails off... but they desperately need more front of house staff. Don't expect efficient service. The ugly: The milkshake. Oy...this was bad. I got a chocolate peanut butter milkshake, and it just wasn't good at all. Very soupy, barely a taste of peanut butter to it at all, and for some random reason there were chocolate chips that kept being sucked up in my straw. I have never had a chocolate shake that featured chocolate chips... a truly odd choice. I really can recommend the hamburger...it was good. But the next time I need my American fix, I'm walking a block over to Five Guys.

WHopckqAm9f9f2rWt88xpg.text: A great place for brunch (with boozy shakes!). Also, they do garlic butter fries. I don't think I need to say more on that front, they ARE as good as they sound!However, don't try to go for the healthy-sounding things, or the build-your-own stuff. Filth is what they do best!!cakeandwhisky.wordpress.…

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Hash browns, The Diner, Islington
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The Diner, Islington
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Milkshake, The Diner, Islington

0zHz9puJNXUEY96QoJyIWQ.text: I can really only base this off one breakfast experience there, but the branding and environment was cute and the staff was sweet, which is why I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 2. I didn't know about the free wi-fi which I just read on Linzi's review in the sidebar, so that gives it an extra solid 3-star boost for me.But on to the breakfast, which was overpriced *for sure*, but plentiful. The American-style pancakes were dense and tasted a lot like lemons, which I found vexing. Being an American, I know my pancakes and these were not it.I also had to be That American and sent my eggs back. I really *really* didn't want to, but for £10 for a simple breakfast, I needed to. They were inedible. Ordered "scrambled" got "fried and minced up with a spatula" and while I would've shut up and eaten that, they were also underdone with shimmying runny whites. Nope. Nope nope.The bacon was bacony. The service, again, was sweet and she took my egg-return in stride without no side-eye or anything. I did take *forever* to get our bill, but I've found that to be the case everywhere I've been thus far in London. It's like they never want you to leave. I love you, London restaurants, but we have places to be!I liked that The Diner had alright bottomless filter coffee for £2.80, which I'll now take advantage of with my laptop and their wi-fi, as I'll inevitably be back since it's right up the street.Plus, I've heard about the boozy shakes and cheese fries now and I'm no fool.

777BgyLiDjf_PPwzcqHdSw.text: As an American...  I wasn't super impressed, but then again, there are plenty of restaurants like this in the states that are mediocre or just plain bad, so in someways it is kind of authentic (do you see what I did there...  yeah...).  It was rather dark inside and I would've appreciated a bit of light to see my food...The staff were really attentive.  My friend ordered the Lumberjack Breakfast and a hazelnut milkshake.  She said that it wasn't like she remembered it, but the milkshake was delicious.  I ordered the Philly Cheesesteak and Chili Cheese Fries.  The Philly Cheesesteak wasn't really what I was expecting, but for an average steak sandwich it was ok, but to clarify, it was not a Philly Cheesesteak.  The Chili Cheese Fries were my favourite part of the meal... not the best I've had, but they did the trick.  In fact, I wished I had ordered the chili, because I quite liked the flavour.  Adding extras gets expensive, but the extras might just be the best part of the meal.  However, in true American style, they did let us split our tabs!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Chili Cheese Fries... yum

ebCbqYxh1dyeBq1SluKxnw.text: Love going here for their milkshakes and more Americanized stuff like pancakes and crispy bacon and hash browns. Went earlier today and had amazing door stop slab of cornbread topped with smashed avocado and chilli, poached eggs and crispy bacon - washed down with a peanut butter milkshake. Seriously yum. Only reason for 3/5 is their decor is becoming really tatty (quite a few ripped seat covers) and usually we have to ask to have the table wiped down. Shame as the food and service is always good.

JjIFzTWQwbYIHTHXr1bfHw.text: I had never been to The Diner and though the decor was a bit dark and the place wasn't very clean, the food made up for it. I enjoyed the burger and cheesey hanger fries. What really makes the flavour here is the amazing burger sauce!! So tasty and moreish. Also the staff are very friendly and helpful. I would go back here.

dQAwjtkn2YsK2K1RTAuqhQ.text: I will preface this review by saying I really enjoy the food at The Diner, and I have had much better experiences at other locations. I am American, and whenever I crave a good ol' burger in London I think of this chain. That being said...I couldn't believe how terrible the service was when we ate at this location back in December. There was a booth just for staff where they are allowed to essentially sit, chat, and play on their phones. I was floored. That is basically all they did while we were there. It was near impossible to get anyone's attention.We were really disappointed. They never even offered to bring us another round of drinks. Also, there were two tables seated near us filled with people who I can only assume were off schedule coworkers. When a waitress did come near our table it was only to fraternize with their friends before going back to the booth. Really unprofessional.

I5IpIdyUof1LyNwJNMrucA.text: I would first like to mention that I was tempted to give this place more stars just to pull up the average! Lots of old one star reviews that certainly didn't reflect my own experience. There's a good choice of food here, which once ordered is served piping hot within a reasonable time of ordering from my experience. I enjoyed my meatloaf, although the mashed potatoes were a little too authentically American Diner-y for my liking- sloppy and tasteless. My partner had a steak sandwich- of which was served rare just as he had requested. He assures me that it was very tasty. His additional side of onion rings were beer battered and so crispy that I had to 'help him out' with a few of them ;) The reason this place doesn't get higher than an average rating is the staff. They somehow make a very small chain restaurant feel like a very large chain restaurant. As in they don't seem enthused about anything that they're doing etcetera. This could be due to the fact that service charge is added to your bill, so they don't feel like they have to earn it etc. Nobody was particularly rude so we paid the charge, but we had multiple uncaring servers so wouldn't have tipped otherwise. Milkshakes, coke floats and diner booths along with good standard American food make this a place that's A-ok for lunch around Islington though.

vbE1aR63c8E_9cOvtpxC5A.text: This milkshake game is on point. Ya'll don't know. Quit your job and come spend your loot on this banana chocolate shake. Forget sex. F**** it. Ya'll don't need it. This milkshake is the new doggie style.

dHo4We4bmU_2U8MZMdGKqw.text: The mac and cheese + hard milkshake combo is really good and keeps me coming back but the service is the slowest and nobody ever refills your water. It's actually so frustrating that I've started getting my food to go and just eating it at home, that was I can get a drink when I need one. I do appreciate this place for having French's mustard though. What a nice American touch!

n4TP6SGXzY8Ys1PW9K3aow.text: We went for breakfast. It was disastrous. Ages to get seated. Ages to order. Then absolutely AGES to get food. 45 minutes for pancakes? And when we asked where they were we were told it was because they were made from scratch....1) making pancake batter from scratch takes approximately 3 minutes2) why are you making it from scratch when it should really stand for a while anyway3) I don't believe you45 minutes later, our food NEARLY made it to the table before being spectacularly launched into the air off the tray by the waitress, to land in a puddle on the floor right next to us. I nearly cried in frustration. Then the order was wrong. We had to raise our voices and get rather cross to get a discount on a breakfast which took an hour to arrive, was incorrect, and didn't taste that great anyway. It was greasy.The staff were both unfriendly and complacent.The coffee was lukewarm and too small, and not really a flat white. Don't go here for breakfast. Or in fact at all. .

TjfAHLXar27VALgeav5mnA.text: Feels like America when I was eating here. This place offers you a range of burger selection complete with the sides you have been craving for and milkshakes. Their burger is mouthful, it literally is the size of my mouth. But it tasted so well, even better with the fries and a bit of jalapeño to spice it up. The staff was wonderful. They asked me how I want the meat to be and recommended if I wanted any sides with it. When my food came, it looked so yummy and made me decided to put away the utensils and ate it with bare hands instead. The beef patty was just like the way I wanted it and it comes with bright red jalapeño and blue cheese, all served to perfection. All the fries were good. The sweet potato was special and cheesy fries was absolutely luscious. I could still smell the blue cheese and onion on my fingers after the diner. But I loved it. It made me want to come back.
